abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. Key lessons learned include: 1) It
            was demonstrated that large scale projects can be used to
            address village level needs at considerable speed, and that
            villages are able to be the subjects of development instead
            of the object of development. 2) The Kecamatan Development
            Project pilot implementation took as much effort as a full
            project. Thus, the team has become wary of the usefulness of
            pilots. 3) Independent monitoring cannot be relied upon to
            detect problems quickly for corrections on the way, at least
            when local monitoring capcity is weak and foreign experts
            are costly, as in Indonesia. 4) Involving the audit agency
            during project preparation is useful, to avoid the agency
            later requiring documents that are not foreseen in
            innovative project designs. 5) It is worth reviewing the
            methodology for using the SUSENAS (household expenditure
            survey) data in the estimation of poverty incidences in
            Indonesia. 6) In terms of infrastructure: a) bridges built
            by the public works department should be inspected more
            regularly; b) sanitation system for rural areas should be
            looked at carefully, since such construction needs parallel
            education to be fully effective, and such education is
            costly; and c) since faucets available for water systems are
            of poor quality, it may be better to do without them and use
            local approaches.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Village Infrastructure Project
            for Java

abstracts.cdata!:
The Village Infrastructure Project for
            Java aims at providing public infrastructure and employment
            in 1,200 villages, the bottom 20 percent of the poorest or 6
            percent of all rural villages on Java. It includes a 2-3
            year pilot program to increase government decentralization,
            transparency and village participation. Main features are:
            1) empowering villagers to decide, with some economic
            criteria, priority uses of the village grant under the
            project; 2) creation of jobs paid in cash for poor
            villagers, especially in periods of underemployment; 3)
            development of skills for constructing small public works -
            engineering assistance will be provided to villagers to help
            with subproject design and achieving good quality works; 4)
            channelling of village grants through subdistrict branches
            of Bank Rakyat Indonesia; and 5) a monitoring program to
            review progress while the project is underway and overall
            results, expost.

docna.cdata!:
Indonesia - Village Infrastructure Project
            for Java
